title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with evidence showing disparities in legal representation and execution rates. The House Judiciary Subcommittee found that 89% of defendants selected for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. Additionally, a 1990 report by the General Accounting Office highlighted racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts, even with compelling evidence of innocence. Legislation in 1996 limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. The Federal Government and States are prohibited from carrying out the death penalty until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will remain in place until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President. The Commission includes prosecutors, defense attorneys, and judges. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, current or former Federal or State judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The President must ensure a balanced membership with varying opinions on the death penalty. Initial appointments should be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission's initial meeting must occur within 30 days after all initial appointments. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for business. The President designates a Chair, and the Commission adopts rules and procedures for its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles and fairness. This study includes examining racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in capital cases, and the adequacy of representation for defendants. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty to ensure alignment with constitutional principles and fairness. This includes examining racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality, adequacy of representation for capital defendants, wrongful convictions, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, and adequacy of court exercise. The Commission is studying various aspects of the death penalty administration, including racial disparities, adequacy of representation, wrongful convictions, and federal government seeking death penalty in states without it. Key issues being examined include independent judgment in constitutional claims, sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, access to forensic evidence, and ensuring fair and impartial administration of death penalty cases. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty to ensure fairness, impartiality, and due process. Guidelines and procedures will be established to minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals. The Commission is studying the administration of the death penalty to ensure fairness, impartiality, and due process, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination in its administration. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the enactment of this Act to the President, Attorney General, and Congress. The Commission will submit a report to the President, Attorney General, and Congress containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 203. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary to fulfill its duties under this title. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to compel witnesses and evidence. Subpoenas must be signed by the Chairperson and enforced by the district court in cases of non-compliance. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for testimony and evidence, which must be enforced by the district court in cases of non-compliance. The court can order individuals to testify or produce evidence, with failure to comply punishable as contempt. Additionally, a court can issue a writ of habeas for testimony from a person in custody upon application by the Attorney General. The Commission can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to bring a person in custody before them or their designated staff for testimony. Witness allowances and fees will be paid in accordance with section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws, subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission may set the compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services without interrupting civil service status or privilege. Services can be obtained at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It may spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
